messages.text: does anyone know if there are tricks / issues with the number of BLAS threads on ARM ? We have a server where a given function seems to use one thread for blas operations, when the same code uses multiple threads on an intel architecture

elements.text: does anyone know if there are tricks / issues with the number of BLAS threads on ARM ? We have a server where a given function seems to use one thread for blas operations, when the same code uses multiple threads on an intel architecture

messages.text: This will be up to BLAS’s internal threading decision-making

elements.text: This will be up to BLAS’s internal threading decision-making

messages.text: I’m assuming you’re using OpenBLAS

elements.text: I’m assuming you’re using OpenBLAS

messages.text: for e.g. `gemm` the threading/no threading calculation is basically this:

elements.text: for e.g.
gemm
the threading/no threading calculation is basically this:

messages.text: <https://github.com/xianyi/OpenBLAS/blob/f6e4cf2f9dac6f90b36f49659d883767d63791f5/interface/gemm.c#L423-L427>
`MNK` should be the same across platforms, but `GEMM_MULTITHREAD_THRESHOLD` will change from system to system

elements.text: MNK
should be the same across platforms, but
GEMM_MULTITHREAD_THRESHOLD
will change from system to system

messages.text: Sadly, there’s not an easy way to figure out what the threshold has been baked into the library as

elements.text: Sadly, there’s not an easy way to figure out what the threshold has been baked into the library as

messages.text: you’d need to look at some cmake status files while building OpenBLAS to see what value its bootstrapping program decided upon

elements.text: you’d need to look at some cmake status files while building OpenBLAS to see what value its bootstrapping program decided upon

messages.text: it’s possible that it’s not tuned correctly

elements.text: it’s possible that it’s not tuned correctly

messages.text: if you’d like to chase this down, I can help guide you :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: if you’d like to chase this down, I can help guide you

messages.text: thanks! I asked to gain access to the arm server, will update here whenever I can investigate what is going on

elements.text: thanks! I asked to gain access to the arm server, will update here whenever I can investigate what is going on

messages.text: OK I finally have access to an ARM machine for some fun. On my AMD, Int is Int64, and BlasInt is Int64, but using Julia 1.5 for ARM, the 64 bits (there is no 32 anyway), Int is Int64, but BlasInt is Int32, is that expected?

elements.text: OK I finally have access to an ARM machine for some fun. On my AMD, Int is Int64, and BlasInt is Int64, but using Julia 1.5 for ARM, the 64 bits (there is no 32 anyway), Int is Int64, but BlasInt is Int32, is that expected?

messages.text: This led to being able to create a vector with size > max(Int32), but getting an error when calling norm on it

elements.text: This led to being able to create a vector with size > max(Int32), but getting an error when calling norm on it

messages.text: I'll post an issue if this is indeed not expected, just didn't want to spam if this is just a misunderstanding on my end

messages.text:
Maybe this is the right channel for Apple M1 questions? I’m getting stack traces which are short-to-missing, is this a known problem?
```julia> sqrt(-1)
ERROR: DomainError with -1.0:
sqrt will only return a complex result if called with a complex argument. Try sqrt(Complex(x)).
Stacktrace:
 [1] throw_complex_domainerror(f::Symbol, x::Float64)
   @ Base.Math ./math.jl:33

julia> Matrix{Int}([1 2; 3 4.5])
ERROR: InexactError: Int64(4.5)```
This is on master, but I don’t have an intel computer here to compare.

messages.text: I believe this is the “unwinding from JIT frames doesn’t work” checkbox in the aarch64 Darwin tracking issue

elements.text: I believe this is the “unwinding from JIT frames doesn’t work” checkbox in the aarch64 Darwin tracking issue

messages.text: <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/36617#issue-655127468>
I suggest opening an issue.  A comparable `master` build on x86_64 darwin gives the proper, full backtrace

master
build on x86_64 darwin gives the proper, full backtrace

messages.text: Is there a discussion of BinaryBuilder & ARM anywhere? For instance HWloc.jl can’t be loaded, which blocks many packages. I am mostly clueless but it appears to be possible to make hwloc locally by hand, would it be easy or impossible to update Hwloc_jll.jl? I haven’t managed to find issues about this.

messages.text: The jll should be at 2.4.1, which is the current upstream release.

elements.text: The jll should be at 2.4.1, which is the current upstream release.

messages.text: And it does build for `supported_platforms()` which includes aarch64 and armv7l afaik (<https://github.com/JuliaPackaging/Yggdrasil/blob/d367f0ccd85b6b5e2b490459667e1b011988e621/H/Hwloc/build_tarballs.jl#L23>)
